etymologies: early 18th century; earliest use found in Ephraim Chambers (?1680–1740), encyclopaedist. From French mortier

definitions: In France: a cap worn by various officials as an emblem of high office.

notes.text: The mortier was formerly worn by the Chancellor of France and the Presidents of the French parliaments and is now worn, in a modified form, by senior officials and magistrates of the Cour des Comptes (the National Audit Office) and the Cour de Cassation (the Supreme Court of Appeal).
